I have participated in both of the successful investigations and impeachments of President Trump. I also voted for impeachment in each case. As you may recall, Speaker Pelosi and the Democrats controlled the House in both the prior Trump impeachments. As a result, Democrats controlled the impeachment process.

However, right now the Republicans are in control of the House of Representatives. Instead of Speaker Pelosi, Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), a Trump lapdog, is the presiding officer in the House. Therefore, under the Rules of the House any Democratic effort to present Articles of impeachment against President Trump in the current Republican-controlled House will be required to be presented to the Chair of the Judiciary Committee, Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) who is also a shameless tool for the current President.

As Chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Mr. Jordan will control the entire impeachment process. Mr. Jordan will have the power to subpoena friendly witnesses, and to discredit any evidence against Trump. Mr. Jordan will control the voting process, and he will control the result in which the Republican majority will no doubt find Trump innocent of all charges.

Ultimately because the Republicans have a significant majority on the Judiciary Committee, Mr. Jordan will be able to refuse to send the Articles of Impeachment to the floor so that Mr. Green’s resolution will never be voted on in the House. It will be dead on arrival. A fool’s errand.

Anyone who tells you differently has a poor understanding of the Rules of the U.S. House of Representatives. Plain and simple.

As a member of the House @OversightDems , which has been included as a Committee of jurisdiction during past impeachments, I firmly believe that our investigative time and resources are much better spent conducting extensive oversight of the Trump Administration and preparing an investigative record that will be primed and ready for a Democratic majority to hold President Trump fully accountable when we retake the majority in the midterm elections 17 months from now.

Our House Democratic Litigation and Rapid Response Task Force is also supporting more than 280 lawsuits filed by State Attorneys General, federal employee unions, pro-democracy and civil rights advocates, and other organizations against the Trump Administration.  To date, federal courts nationwide have issued nearly 200 court orders to block or suspend unlawful Trump Administration actions.

Democrats have a number of ongoing investigations into the blatantly wrongful conduct on the part of President Trump, his family, his business partners and his Administration including his self-dealing and cryptocurrency schemes, his sale of government access and services as well as his acceptance of payments and emoluments from foreign leaders. The list of offenses continues to grow.

For those of you who have sent messages or have called my office, I understand your frustration and your desire for “impeachment now”. However, as I described above, to do so with the Republicans in charge of the impeachment process would be a colossal failure, a wasted opportunity and a gift to President Trump and his henchmen.

With so much at stake, we must be patient, we must be vigilant, we must be smart and highly disciplined and yet be relentless in our resistance at every turn.

Sincerely, U.S. Rep. Stephen F. Lynch

Last night the House passed the American Relief Act to prevent a senseless government shutdown. It provides $100.4B in disaster relief funding for the entire country, which includes $29B for FEMA’s Disaster Relief fund, $250M to increase access to childcare for working families, and $552M for our State of Massachusetts. The Commonwealth will receive $7.75M for federal highway emergency relief, $11M for agriculture disaster relief, and $7.95M for Community Development Block Grant disaster recovery for post-disaster assistance with housing and infrastructure needs. Notably, Congress also completed action on the Social Security Fairness Act, which repeals the Windfall Elimination penalty and Government Pension Offset for many Social Security recipients.
